Description: Copper alloy arrow-head with short triangular barbed point, trefoil section and socket. Also known as trilobate, or 'Scythian type'.
Curator's comments: See London, BM, EA 23928, and GR 1935, 0823.96, similar type

Socketed trilobate arrow-heads are common in the Middle East from the 7th century BC and subsequently in Greece and Egypt. This short barbed type has good parallels from the Classical period until at least 364BC (the battle of Altis) (Baitinger 2001, 23, figs 355-366, Type IIB5). During the course of the 4th century BC, arrow heads tend to become larger and this type is abandoned. Baitinger, H. 2001, Die Angriffswaffen aus Olympia, Berlin & New York.
Bibliographic references: Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.73, p.183, pl.25)
